review_title: Incredible mission, people, and opportunity to grow and make a significant impact on the world.
pros: mission, purpose-driven, impactful, professional development
cons: It's large and complex organization.

pros: The people (staff and members) are GREAT! Access to connect with a global network of ULI colleagues to learn best practices within their district councils. Diverse industry exposure as for members and content. Talented and professional colleagues that partner on programs who are also responsive, caring, and excellence driven. Very good benefits. Mission-oriented organization so opportunities exist to "do good" and deliver on the core values of the organization via content, education, convenings, partnerships, etc. Has the propensity to be a world-class nonprofit with the talent behind it.
cons: This feedback may be district centric, so please take that into consideration. Too busy to pause and reflect on past projects -- would benefit from not over-calendaring events so staff can summarize and incorporate better practices or new messaging, partnerships, etc. Understaffed as for "workers" doing the planning and execution on the core work per district council offerings. Salary increases are far and few between. Goal setting process is good but then the follow-through per district council is not. Accountability and how they play into your review is a nonstarter. Salaries need to be increased more regularly and fairly to meet the cost of living and body of work delivering. Needs a nonprofit CRM tool for sponsor tracking and metrics management.

pros: great networking opportunities, respected industry resource
cons: lack of mobility, hard to get promoted by merit

pros: Pretty chill environment, conferences are cool, lots of networking opportunities
cons: pay is terrible, lots of turnover, lots of self important people who think theyre changing the world (theyre not)

job_title: Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great mission and a good team spirit
cons: Very political and struggles to adapt to new ways of working with enough pace

pros: Benefits, paid holidays, weeks off for holidays in December, flexibility
cons: Pay could be better for HQ since DC is expensive

pros: Mission-driven organization, good mission priorities Good benefits Kind and helpful colleagues
cons: Low Salaries No opportunities for professional growth/development Managers not given adequate training

pros: Unofficial benefit of closing office (with pay) the week between Christmas and New Years, that was great. Also seem to be taking discussions of organization's past and present role in advancing DEI in real estate seriously.
cons: Chronic understaffing, so there was no regard at all for work-life balance. Expectation was that you could be reached at any time, even weekends or late at night. Bosses set unrealistic timelines, and always made it seem like there was no acceptable time to take a day off. Leadership tolerates toxic middle-managers who are well connected or who have a history of delivering results. Benefits advertised at hiring were later suspended for multiple years due to covid (Tuition reimbursement, 401k match).

pros: positive work culture. lots of improvements
cons: salaries are lower than other in the area

pros: Most staff can get away without working too hard and not be held to account
cons: Bad leadership - especially CEO (Walter) and the Americas leader (Cote) no clue who is supposed to be doing what.

pros: The mission of the organization is outstanding, and working with members around the globe is incredibly rewarding.
cons: The environment is extremely toxic. There is no open door policy and no transparency. Senior staff is constantly being rotated out, either getting fired or being encouraged to leave. Taking a vacation was near impossible - expectations were to be working and responding daily no matter what. Decisions have to be made by what feels like a team of 25 people. Nothing is easy to execute. Most jobs require a masters in urban planning or similar field but the roles are truly administrative.

pros: Flexible, learning opportunities, influence, impact
cons: disjointed with national HQ, event planning

pros: The senior associates are all amazing and the office is very nice.
cons: Too much disorganization in teams working on reports with the strict deadlines. This leads to working way too much overtime, including on weekends. Some managers are toxic and do not respect the time of senior associates or associates. The pay (65k) is not commensurate with the number of hours worked, and there is no compensation for overtime.

pros: Flexibility and fast-paced environment made this a great place to work.
cons: The pay was not great.

review_title: Company review for Director position at ULI
pros: Great national network; amazing opportunities for professional development and continued education; ability to move up within the organization until a certain point.
cons: Work/life balance; salary equity and transparency amongst comparable leadership levels and positions within the organization.

review_title: Engage with all aspects of land use
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Well-resourced, mission driven organization. Opportunities to interact and collaborate with leaders in land use and real estate. Good reputation and good benefits. Connect with network of staff and member leaders from around the world.
cons: Hours can be a bit challenging with early morning and evening events.

pros: Competitive Paid Time Off and Holiday calendar
cons: Communication between teams has been an ongoing work in progress

pros: Great benefits, engaging content, feel like your able to help make changes in your community
cons: people treat you like you are an event planner, the National office does not give great support to local District Councils but it is getting better, hours can be odd sometimes

pros: Great opportunity to network and meet real estate professionals across all sectors. You will build key skills that will assist you in other jobs.
cons: There is limited upward mobility.

pros: great community, good people, remote working
cons: not very well paid jobs

review_title: Interesting job, great opportunities to learn
pros: Working as staff at a district council (as opposed to the HQ office) can be tremendously rewarding; great for relationship-building and learning the local real estate and planning landscape.
cons: Lots of administrative work as part of a lean team - but we do it all - from moving tables at events to broad strategy for an annual work program.

pros: Interesting network of members and stimulating topics.
cons: There is an enormous lack of loyalty, honesty and ethics within management which produces a great deal of stress, unhappiness and turnover within.

pros: The staff is passionate and smart
cons: The turnover rate is not surprising. All the great staff leaves due to horrific leadership in DC.

pros: ULI is a great organization with a great mission. Employees are really committed to the mission. There are ample opportunities for career advancement and professional development. ULI's CEO and leadership are committed to making it a better place to work especially with DEI being a priority for leadership. In regards to work-life balance and job satisfaction, it can vary from team to team or can be dependent on the manager of that team but overall it's a positive work environment. Compensation is competitive according to the market (nonprofit) and geographic area and there are always opportunities to increase compensation.
cons: The HQ office is in Washington D.C. so it can be quite a commute depending on where you live but there are some teams/managers who are open to telework.

pros: learn a lot quickly and stepping stone for more advanced career
cons: poor pay, disorganized teams and poor interoffice communication

pros: huge office, great culture, and decent hours.
cons: capitalism will destroy the world

pros:
- DC office is really nice
- Culture is friendly, open, and collaborative
- Launching many staff & member programs
- Office parties and conventions are a lot of fun
cons:
- Non-profit salary
- Poor job stability in COVID
- Organization isn't very tech focused and it's difficult to get everyone to adopt new SOPs and technology platforms.

pros: Great programs that have a positive impact on communities. Strong brand in the real estate world.
cons: Serves as a member organization which takes away from non profit work.

pros: Atmosphere, good team, everyone works together well across departments, love the office space
cons: Generally there are small team sizes

review_title: Great organization with a great purpose
pros:
Remote work opportunities
Travel opportunities
Opportunities for growth
Excellent benefits
cons: Salaries not as competitive as for-profit companies

review_title: Great company if you don't work at HQ
pros:
*Interesting work 
*High-energy and fast paced environment
*Lots of opportunity to lead projects
*Work is very entrepreneurial and consultant like, especially if you help staff the advisory services projects.
cons:
*Management at HQ is constantly changing and very top heavy (multiple CEO positions, several of them in flux after only 1 year with the company)
*HQ seeks little input on major organizational changes from district council staff, where the majority of member engagement and impact happens
*HQ says the organization is about member engagement, but does little to provide staff support to district councils in that mission 
*There is a preference at HQ to throw technology around a lot as both a staff and member tool, without understanding the real impact on time it has for district council staff
*HQ would be better served to restructure their operations, letting go layers of VPs, Senior VPs, and Executive VPs with redundant and overlapping job responsibilities and deploy those resources to DC staff.

pros: Smart people, nice offices, good benefits
cons: High turnover, poor leadership, no growth

job_title: Senior Vice President Sales in London, England
pros: Very mission focused creating great team dynamics and collaboration.
cons: Regional management competes with HQ leading to frustrated strategic goals and inconsistencies

pros:
Company has a good reputation within the industry
Benefits are moderately good
Good stepping stone to something else
cons:
The work load is overwhelming - there is no compensation for how much you are asked to do
Support for regular employees is dismal--if you are a remote employee, it's non-existant
Poor supervision of remote locations by national organization
Remote employees can feel lost and adrift, with no recourse if local management is problematic

review_title: Caught between interesting and valuable work and an identify crisis at HQ
pros: ULI produces a lot of great work and makes a meaningful difference in how real estate and land use professionals view the world. Working at a District Council grants a certain amount of freedom to be entrepreneurial and responsive to local needs.
cons: The membership structure needs to be reevaluated. An increasing focus on promoting a certain level of exclusivity based on the type of member you are seems to conflict with the idea of promoting learning and better outcomes in communities. The flip side of the positive parts of working at a District Council is that it can feel disconnected from ULI Global.

review_title: okay place for a first job
pros: Everyone who works at ULI is pretty nice and easy to get along with except the executives (They're like programmed robots who just give you the sideeye with a fake smile). Traveling opportunities come with nice views and exploring. I gained a lot of work experience, and had the chance to enhance my leadership and manager skills.
cons: Low Pay, Senior & executive management don't pass down proper info (just give you tasks and expect you to do it). Very high turn over, and understaffed like crazy. So be prepared to be overworked, under paid, and highly stressed.

review_title: Great Learning Experience / Awful Environment at ULI HQ in DC
pros:
If you are interested in the content and plan to work in the field of real estate development/planning/architecture later on, this is a good place to have on your resume. Most of the staff and ULI members are fantastic connections to have, and there is a growing population of young, smart, innovative people coming in (albeit at the junior level). 

The benefits are good and recently seem to be expanding a bit (401K matching; dental/vision/health coverage; good parental leave policy; nice, open office with plants in a great location; good IT team; some professional development). 

Potential for travel to really cool places, but only if you are on the right team and/or you suck up to management. Work/Life balance has been really great so far. 

The new Global CEO is great and has tons of good ideas, but has been slow so far in making real, lasting change.
cons:
The culture here is not great. It's not an enjoyable place to work, and no one really seems to care. I'm not quite sure what we're selling anymore. There is also currently a cloud of worry of a real estate bubble burst, which is bad news for a member association like ULI. 

Management (for the most part) is an absolute mess, to the point they are actively bad mouthing each other behind each others backs, but in front of other staff. I've experienced this several times already. Lots of tugging back and forth at the top level that leaves the rest of us wondering what we're supposed to be doing and where the organization is heading. Many don't feel comfortable or safe expressing this to management. 

Management only seems to care about the 1% of members who are the most wealthy and will give back to ULI through the annual fund. They are called "Key Leaders," and it's sickening to watch how much they control what we do as an organization. 

The turnover is picking up at alarming rate (from junior level all the way to the president). 

It's a nonprofit, so pay is not great. But it gets worse when you realize that good performance does not equal more pay. So far, everyone gets the same small raise every year, so make sure you negotiate when you are hired.

We are trying to do entirely too much with the amount of staff that we have. Everyone is spread so thin that there is a clear "quantity over quality" culture throughout. 

Definite silo-ing happening between DC HQ staff and all the rest of the great District Council staff, who honestly have more insight into what our members actually want.

pros: Awesome environment and mentors. You learn a lot about urban development and all the work that goes into making connections with the right businesses that will help benefit such a successful non profit.
cons: There were barely any cons. I was on the job, they treated me like an employee and not an intern and what you experience will help you down the road if you are planning on going into urban development.

review_title: Advisory Services,  Content teams are great  places to work at ULI
pros: The Advisory Services and Content teams provide great opportunities for employment for those who are interested in urban planning and development. Staff members are dedicated to ULI's mission and it shows in their strong work ethic.
cons: For ULI as a whole, better team-to-team communication is needed to fully support the work of Advisory Services, Content teams and other mission-driven areas of the organization.

pros: Company has an open office, multiple locations, offers flexibility, great mission.
cons: High turnover from the top down to the bottom, which doesn't make anyone feel stable in the organization. Employees are underpaid and overworked.

pros:
Given a lot of autonomy and freedom to try new things.
Co-workers were very helpful and supportive
Company strived to be current with latest trends
cons:
Workload can be overwhelming
Communication is not a strong suit of the organization
Departments often act in isolation
Information is often not disseminated in a timely manner

pros: None at this time. Great Marketing Team
cons: Lack of appreciation, no positive motivation, favorite employees and no changes expected to this in the future. Performance based pay increase a joke! No one other than upper management gets paid any where near industry standards! There is no where to complain. We have a non existent HR department which is rude and unresponsive.

pros:
Great offices and equipment.
They had meetings and conferences that really brought colleagues together. Depending on who you work with, you can really learn a lot in the environment and conduct a lot of meaningful research.
cons: High turnover rate, probably because they barely pay their employees that are lower than the manager position. Also, higher-ups yelling at subordinates in an open office is... not great.

review_title: Opportunities if you can get past the nonsense
pros: Opportunities for building your network, having autonomy to complete projects, and general professional growth and development by engaging on local issues with members
cons: Non competitive pay, chaos at HQ, no training, no internal communications, no respect or care for staff

pros: There is a strong opportunity to make excellent contacts from Mayors to builders to finance gurus.
cons: Most staff are not aligned with the mission of the company.  The salary is not great.  Staff training needs are ignored.

review_title: ULI is a great place to work
pros:
- Amazing colleagues who are incredibly smart, forward thinking, and mission driven
- The work has an impact in society
- Fun culture: happy hours, summer Fridays, closed between Christmas & New Year
cons: - Relationships between remote staff and those working at headquarters could be improved.

pros:
-Good Benefits though health insurance options could have been better
-Modern equipment and systems
-Opportunities to move around the company
-Young work environment
cons:
-Cube Farm work space, no privacy
-Saw some abusive managers
-My dept. was characteristically unfriendly
-Pay was ok

pros: I've been a member of ULI for a few year now. They do a really good job at engaging their members, especially their Young Leaders Group.
cons: Having been a member of ULI in two areas, I can definitely see the difference in how they differ. There isn't a set "agenda"  or "structure" so it seems .

review_title: Great access to real estate and land use membership - very fulfilling.
pros: Member-driven organization with smart, exciting, capable members
cons: Low pay for lower-level staff

pros: The coordinator of ULI St. Louis is really nice. She is patient, enthusiastic. I have appreciated her help for career path a lot.
cons: The data research work is difficult at the beginning. Some data is difficult to be found. I have got help from librarian.

pros: Mission-focused work can be rewarding.
cons: While salaries are standard nonprofit level (unless you’re a senior executive making very high six figures), the culture at ULI is dominated by toxic internal politics, presenteeism and “workaholism”.  It can be a soul destroying place to work if you’re not at the very top.

review_title: There was a lot of internal chaos at HQ
pros:
Really interesting subject matter.
Passionate people (particularly in local chapters)
You get to meet fascinating and community-oriented members
cons: Lots of internal turf wars, not just between departments at the staff level, but among some member in leadership.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good team, good people working at the district council level. Very good opportunities for networking and meeting people in real estate.
cons:
Disorganization at the highest levels of the organization causes problems downstream. 

Need to invest in newer technology like sales force.

review_title: Good organization but poor management in local offices
pros: Great benefits, educational learning, great for networking and building relationships.
cons: Local offices have no HQ oversight on Executive Directors and how they manage their employees.

pros: Great networking opportunities, lots of great content- newsletters, summit, leadership classes, etc.
cons: No room for growth, seems to be dominated by developers and  not that balanced between urban planners or architects

pros: Wonderful company and wonderful members!
cons: Not that many cons...it's non profit so pay isn't as high but it's a great place to work!

pros: Friendly, welcoming work environment, good communication, clear path for growth, great mission, good work/life balance
cons: I haven't identified any cons yet

pros: Excellent access to leaders in all aspects of land planning.
cons: Low resources, volunteer-run which can lead to disorganization and low ownership of projects.

pros: Open office, friendly coworkers, great benefits, interdisciplinary work
